p: The primary outcome of the study was olfactory dysfunction of the responders at the onset of their problem and its condition at the time of their response to the questionnaire, which was measured by closed questions and scored by Likert scale. Secondary outcomes were clinical manifestations of participants such as flu or cold symptoms before anosmia, headache that needed a pain reliever drug, nasal stiffness, fever and chills, prominent cough, orbital (periorbital) pain, facial fullness and sinus pain, rhinorrhea, dyspnea, nasal irritation, parosmia, nasal pruritus, history of hypothyroidism, otalgia, sneezing (frequent), purulent nasal discharge, history of asthma, cheeks pain, previous sinus surgery or septorhinoplasty, unilateral facial palsy, and a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperthyroidism.
